title: Ruth Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ruth chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ruth Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ruth Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who was the kinsman of Naomi's husband mentioned in Ruth 2:1?
options: Boaz
Elimelech
Mahlon
Chilion
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:1 states that Boaz was the kinsman of Naomi's husband.

questions.question: What did Ruth ask Naomi permission to do in Ruth 2:2?
options: Go to the field to glean ears of corn
Visit Bethlehem
Marry Boaz
Prepare food for Naomi
questions.correctAnswer: Go to the field to glean ears of corn
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:2 shows Ruth asking Naomi to go to the field to glean ears of corn.

questions.question: Where did Ruth end up gleaning according to Ruth 2:3?
options: In the field of Boaz
In the city market
In Naomi's garden
By the river
questions.correctAnswer: In the field of Boaz
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:3 says Ruth gleaned in the field belonging to Boaz.

questions.question: What greeting did Boaz give to the reapers in Ruth 2:4?
options: The LORD be with you
Peace be upon you
Good morning
Blessings to you
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD be with you
questions.explanation: Boaz greeted the reapers saying, 'The LORD be with you' as per Ruth 2:4.

questions.question: Who did Boaz ask about the young woman gleaning in the field in Ruth 2:5?
options: His servant
Naomi
Ruth herself
The town elders
questions.correctAnswer: His servant
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:5 records Boaz asking his servant about the damsel gleaning.

questions.question: What nationality was Ruth described as in Ruth 2:6?
options: Moabitess
Israelite
Philistine
Egyptian
questions.correctAnswer: Moabitess
questions.explanation: The servant describes Ruth as a Moabitess in Ruth 2:6.

questions.question: True or False: Ruth gleaned in the fields only for a short time before resting in the house according to Ruth 2:7.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:7 states she gleaned from morning until now, then tarried a little in the house.

questions.question: What instruction did Boaz give Ruth about where to glean in Ruth 2:8?
options: Stay close to his maidens and don’t go to other fields
Glean only at the city gates
Follow the servants wherever they go
Return to Naomi immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Stay close to his maidens and don’t go to other fields
questions.explanation: Boaz told Ruth to stay near his maidens and not to glean in other fields as per Ruth 2:8.

questions.question: What assurance did Boaz give Ruth regarding the young men in Ruth 2:9?
options: They will not touch or harm her
They will help her gather grain
They will teach her to glean
They will bring her food
questions.correctAnswer: They will not touch or harm her
questions.explanation: In Ruth 2:9, Boaz assures Ruth that he charged the young men not to touch her.

questions.question: How did Ruth respond to Boaz’s kindness in Ruth 2:10?
options: She bowed down and asked why she found grace in his eyes
She ignored him
She immediately left the field
She called Naomi to meet him
questions.correctAnswer: She bowed down and asked why she found grace in his eyes
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:10 recounts Ruth bowing and asking why she found favor in Boaz’s eyes.

questions.question: What did Boaz acknowledge about Ruth’s actions towards Naomi in Ruth 2:11?
options: All that she has done for her mother-in-law since her husband’s death
Her hard work in the field
Her Moabite heritage
Her kindness to the servants
questions.correctAnswer: All that she has done for her mother-in-law since her husband’s death
questions.explanation: Boaz recognized Ruth’s loyalty and care for Naomi in Ruth 2:11.

questions.question: True or False: Boaz said the LORD would give Ruth a full reward for her work in Ruth 2:12.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:12 states Boaz blessing Ruth with a full reward from the LORD.

questions.question: What did Boaz invite Ruth to do at mealtime in Ruth 2:14?
options: Come eat bread and dip her morsel in vinegar
Rest in his house
Speak to the elders
Drink water from the well
questions.correctAnswer: Come eat bread and dip her morsel in vinegar
questions.explanation: Boaz invited Ruth to eat and dip her morsel in vinegar in Ruth 2:14.

questions.question: True or False: Boaz commanded his young men to rebuke Ruth while she gleaned according to Ruth 2:15.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:15 records Boaz forbidding his men to reproach Ruth while gleaning.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ruth gleaned until ____, and she gathered about an ephah of barley. (Ruth 2:17)
options: even
morning
noon
sunrise
questions.correctAnswer: even
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:17 states she gleaned until evening and gathered about an ephah of barley.

medium.title: Ruth Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ruth Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God in a new environment. Based on Ruth 2, what biblical truth would you share about faith and trust?
options: Trusting God brings protection and blessing as seen in Ruth's experience with Boaz
Faith means avoiding new places to stay comfortable
Trust is only for those born in Israel
God does not care about outsiders
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God brings protection and blessing as seen in Ruth's experience with Boaz
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:12 shows how Ruth found favor under God's wings by trusting Him. Naomi also recognizes God's kindness through Boaz (Ruth 2:20). Ruth's obedience and faith led to God's blessing (Ruth 2:3, 2:8).

questions.question: How does Ruth 2 teach about the value of hard work and integrity in daily life?
options: Ruth diligently gleaned in Boaz's field from morning until evening
Ruth expected others to provide for her without effort
Boaz reproached Ruth for working too hard
Ruth left the field early without gathering much
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth diligently gleaned in Boaz's field from morning until evening
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:7 and 2:17 demonstrate Ruth's perseverance in work, gleaning all day and gathering about an ephah of barley. Boaz commanded his workers to let her glean without reproach (Ruth 2:15-16), affirming the value of honest labor.

questions.question: When facing social and cultural differences, what example of humility and gratitude can we learn from Ruth in chapter 2?
options: Ruth humbly bowed to Boaz and expressed gratitude for his kindness
Ruth demanded equal treatment as a native Israelite
Ruth refused to speak to Boaz because she was a stranger
Ruth boasted about her Moabite heritage
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth humbly bowed to Boaz and expressed gratitude for his kindness
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:10 shows her humility as she bowed to Boaz and asked why she found favor. She also thanked him for his friendly words (Ruth 2:13), modeling gratitude and humility despite being a foreigner.

questions.question: A believer is seeking how to care for family in times of hardship. How does Ruth 2 illustrate faithfulness and loving service within family?
options: Ruth works hard to provide for Naomi, showing loyalty and love
Ruth ignores Naomi and seeks her own gain
Naomi sends Ruth away to fend for herself
Ruth complains about her responsibilities
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth works hard to provide for Naomi, showing loyalty and love
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:2 and 2:18 show Ruth asking to glean to provide food for Naomi. Naomi acknowledges Ruth’s faithfulness and blesses her (Ruth 2:19-20), illustrating sacrificial love and service within family.

questions.question: How does Boaz’s treatment of Ruth teach us about generosity and stewardship in Christian life?
options: Boaz instructs his workers to leave extra grain for Ruth to gather
Boaz refuses to share any food or protection with Ruth
Boaz expects Ruth to pay for permission to glean
Boaz ignores Ruth’s presence in the field
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz instructs his workers to leave extra grain for Ruth to gather
questions.explanation: Boaz commands his young men not to harm Ruth and to purposely drop extra grain for her (Ruth 2:15-16), demonstrating generous stewardship and care for those in need.

questions.question: How does Ruth 2 illustrate the importance of community and fellowship in the church life?
options: Ruth stays close to Boaz’s maidens as part of a supportive community
Ruth isolates herself from others in the field
Ruth works alone and avoids fellowship
Boaz forbids Ruth from interacting with others
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth stays close to Boaz’s maidens as part of a supportive community
questions.explanation: Naomi advises Ruth to stay with Boaz’s maidens for safety and provision (Ruth 2:8, 2:22), highlighting the value of supportive fellowship and community in daily life.

questions.question: What does Ruth's experience in chapter 2 teach about perseverance through trials?
options: Ruth continues gleaning from morning until evening despite being a foreigner
Ruth gives up after a short time in the field
Ruth complains about the difficulties and returns home
Ruth depends solely on others without effort
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth continues gleaning from morning until evening despite being a foreigner
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:7 and 2:17 show her perseverance in gleaning all day long, even in a challenging environment, teaching endurance through trials by faithful labor.

questions.question: How does Boaz’s response to Ruth teach about integrity and protection in the workplace?
options: Boaz commands his men not to touch Ruth and to protect her
Boaz ignores Ruth’s safety in the field
Boaz allows his workers to harass Ruth
Boaz sends Ruth away from the field
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz commands his men not to touch Ruth and to protect her
questions.explanation: Boaz instructs his young men not to touch or reproach Ruth while she works (Ruth 2:9, 2:15), demonstrating workplace integrity and care for vulnerable workers.

questions.question: How does Ruth 2 encourage believers to respond to kindness and blessings received?
options: Ruth responds with humility and thanksgiving to Boaz’s kindness
Ruth takes kindness for granted without gratitude
Ruth demands more than what is offered
Ruth ignores Boaz’s generosity
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth responds with humility and thanksgiving to Boaz’s kindness
questions.explanation: Ruth humbly bows and thanks Boaz for his favor and words (Ruth 2:10, 2:13), teaching believers to respond to blessings with gratitude and humility.

questions.question: True or False: Naomi was unaware of Boaz’s kindness toward Ruth and did not bless him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Naomi acknowledges Boaz’s kindness and blesses him for not leaving off his kindness to the living and the dead (Ruth 2:20), showing awareness and gratitude.

questions.question: True or False: Ruth was instructed by Boaz to glean in many different fields for variety.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Boaz instructs Ruth to stay in his field and close to his maidens, not to go to other fields (Ruth 2:8, 2:22), emphasizing safety and provision through focused diligence.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment and gratitude despite being a foreigner or outsider. What lesson from Ruth 2 would you share?
options: Ruth found grace and favor despite being a stranger through humility and faithful work
Ruth was rejected because she was not from Israel
Being a foreigner is a barrier to God’s blessing
Ruth demanded to be treated as a native
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth found grace and favor despite being a stranger through humility and faithful work
questions.explanation: Ruth humbly acknowledges her outsider status but finds favor in Boaz’s eyes due to her faithfulness (Ruth 2:10-12), teaching contentment and trust in God’s provision.

questions.question: Based on Ruth 2, how should believers approach the balance of work and rest?
options: Ruth worked diligently all day but rested to eat and refresh herself
Ruth worked without breaks or meals
Ruth avoided hard work and rested excessively
Boaz did not provide any food for Ruth
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth worked diligently all day but rested to eat and refresh herself
questions.explanation: Boaz invited Ruth to eat at mealtime (Ruth 2:14), and she continued gleaning until evening (Ruth 2:17), showing a balance of diligent work with proper refreshment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Naomi said to Ruth, 'Blessed be he of the LORD, who hath not left off his ______ to the living and to the dead.'
options: kindness
anger
judgment
silence
questions.correctAnswer: kindness
questions.explanation: Naomi blesses Boaz for his continued kindness (Ruth 2:20), demonstrating the biblical virtue of recognizing and appreciating God’s blessings through others.

questions.question: How does Ruth 2 demonstrate the blessing of godly leadership and mentorship?
options: Boaz provides protection, provision, and guidance to Ruth
Boaz ignores Ruth’s needs and leaves her unprotected
Boaz competes with Ruth for resources
Boaz scolds Ruth for gleaning
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz provides protection, provision, and guidance to Ruth
questions.explanation: Boaz takes a leadership role by instructing his workers to protect Ruth, providing food and guidance (Ruth 2:8-9, 2:15-16), illustrating godly mentoring.

hard.title: Ruth Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ruth Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who is Boaz described as in relation to Naomi's husband?
options: A mighty man of wealth and kinsman
A foreigner from Moab
A servant in Bethlehem
A prophet of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A mighty man of wealth and kinsman
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:1 identifies Boaz as a kinsman of Naomi's husband and a mighty man of wealth from the family of Elimelech.

questions.question: What does Ruth request permission to do in Ruth 2:2?
options: To glean ears of corn in the fields
To go to the city marketplace
To visit her family in Moab
To seek employment in a wealthy house
questions.correctAnswer: To glean ears of corn in the fields
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:2 records Ruth asking Naomi to let her go glean ears of corn after someone in whose sight she may find favor.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Israel, what does 'gleaning' signify as illustrated by Ruth's actions?
options: Collecting leftover grain after harvesters
Tithing crops to the priests
Planting seeds in the fields
Harvesting first-fruits for the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Collecting leftover grain after harvesters
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:3 shows Ruth gleaning after the reapers, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern practice of allowing the poor to gather leftover crops.

questions.question: What greeting does Boaz offer to the reapers, and what is its theological significance?
options: The LORD be with you
Peace be upon you
Greetings from Elimelech
Blessings of the harvest
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD be with you
questions.explanation: Boaz greets the reapers with 'The LORD be with you' in Ruth 2:4, invoking divine presence and blessing, emphasizing Yahweh's role in daily life and work.

questions.question: What does Boaz instruct his young men concerning Ruth?
options: Not to touch her and to allow her to glean freely
To send her away from the fields
To treat her as a servant
To ignore her presence
questions.correctAnswer: Not to touch her and to allow her to glean freely
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:9 and 2:15 show Boaz commanding his men not to touch Ruth and to let her glean without reproach, reflecting protection and kindness.

questions.question: How does Ruth respond when Boaz shows her kindness and concern?
options: She bows down and questions why she found favor
She ignores him and continues working
She asks for payment for her labor
She leaves the field immediately
questions.correctAnswer: She bows down and questions why she found favor
questions.explanation: In Ruth 2:10, Ruth humbly falls on her face and asks why she has found grace in Boaz's eyes, indicating humility and gratitude.

questions.question: What key theme is evident in Boaz's blessing to Ruth about her loyalty and trust?
options: The LORD rewarding faithfulness and refuge under His wings
The importance of economic prosperity
The role of foreign women in Israel
The obligation of kinship redemption
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD rewarding faithfulness and refuge under His wings
questions.explanation: Boaz's blessing in Ruth 2:12 emphasizes God's reward for Ruth's loyalty and her trust under God's protective wings, a metaphor for divine care.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew word translated as 'wings' in Ruth 2:12 most likely symbolize?
options: Divine protection and refuge
Physical wings of an animal
The extremities of a field
A military shield
questions.correctAnswer: Divine protection and refuge
questions.explanation: The term 'wings' (Hebrew: kanaph) in Ruth 2:12 metaphorically represents God's protective care, similar to imagery used in Psalms and other scriptures.

questions.question: How does Boaz's invitation to Ruth at mealtime (Ruth 2:14) function within the narrative's literary structure?
options: It signifies hospitality and inclusion within the community
It marks a turning point to conflict
It emphasizes Ruth's foreignness
It reflects a contractual obligation
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies hospitality and inclusion within the community
questions.explanation: Boaz inviting Ruth to eat with the reapers in Ruth 2:14 illustrates acceptance and kindness, a motif of inclusion amidst social marginalization.

questions.question: What literary device is illustrated by the description of Ruth gleaning 'until even' and then threshing out about an ephah of barley (Ruth 2:17)?
options: Chiastic structure emphasizing abundance
Foreshadowing of Ruth’s future prosperity
Parallelism reflecting labor and reward
Allegory of Israel’s restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism reflecting labor and reward
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:17 uses parallelism between labor (gleaning) and reward (an ephah of barley), highlighting the theme of diligent work yielding sufficient provision.

questions.question: What does Naomi's statement about Boaz in Ruth 2:20 reveal about the cultural practice of kinship in Israel?
options: Boaz is a near kinsman responsible for family redemption
Boaz is a stranger with no family ties
Boaz is a priest overseeing harvests
Boaz is a merchant seeking profit
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz is a near kinsman responsible for family redemption
questions.explanation: Naomi identifies Boaz as a near kinsman in Ruth 2:20, implying his role in the levirate or family redemption customs prevalent in Israelite society.

questions.question: True or False: Ruth only gleaned in Boaz’s field for one day before moving to another.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:23 indicates she stayed close to Boaz's maidens and gleaned in his fields until the end of the barley and wheat harvests, showing persistence.

questions.question: What is the significance of Ruth being a Moabitess gleaning in an Israelite field?
options: It highlights themes of inclusion and God’s providence beyond Israel
It shows the rejection of foreigners in Israel
It symbolizes Moabite political dominance
It emphasizes Israelite purity laws
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights themes of inclusion and God’s providence beyond Israel
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:6 and context show Ruth, a Moabitess, accepted and blessed in Israel, illustrating God's grace extending beyond ethnic Israel.

questions.question: How does Ruth 2 contribute to the theme of covenant faithfulness found throughout the Bible?
options: By demonstrating loyalty to family and God's providence
By depicting legalistic adherence to the law
By illustrating divine judgment on foreigners
By explaining temple rituals for harvest
questions.correctAnswer: By demonstrating loyalty to family and God's providence
questions.explanation: Ruth’s loyalty to Naomi and Boaz’s kindness reflect covenant themes of faithfulness and God’s providential care, linking to broader biblical theology.

questions.question: What does Boaz’s kindness to Ruth foreshadow in the wider biblical narrative?
options: The Messianic lineage through David
The establishment of the temple priesthood
The exile of Israel to Babylon
The conquest of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: The Messianic lineage through David
questions.explanation: Boaz’s relationship with Ruth leads to King David’s lineage (Ruth 4), connecting Ruth 2’s kindness to God’s redemptive plan culminating in the Messiah.

theological.title: Ruth Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ruth Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the significance of Boaz being described as 'a mighty man of wealth' and 'of the family of Elimelech' in Ruth 2:1?
options: It establishes Boaz as a near kinsman and a man of means capable of providing for Ruth and Naomi
It suggests that Boaz was the king of Bethlehem
It indicates that Boaz was a prophet of Israel
It shows that Boaz was a foreigner with no relation to Naomi's family
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes Boaz as a near kinsman and a man of means capable of providing for Ruth and Naomi
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:1 identifies Boaz as a kinsman of Elimelech's family, making him a potential redeemer under the Levitical law (cf. Leviticus 25:25; Deuteronomy 25:5). His wealth signifies God's providence and blessing, enabling him to support Ruth and Naomi. This connects to biblical themes of covenant faithfulness and God's provision (cf. Proverbs 3:9-10; Genesis 48:15-16; 2 Corinthians 9:8).

questions.question: How does Ruth's request to glean in the field 'after him in whose sight I shall find grace' (Ruth 2:2) reflect her faith and dependence on God's providence?
options: It shows Ruth's trust in God's sovereign provision through human agents
It indicates Ruth's desire to work independently without help
It reveals Ruth's plan to marry whoever owns the field
It suggests Ruth was seeking to take advantage of the landowners
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Ruth's trust in God's sovereign provision through human agents
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:2 reveals her faith to seek favor or grace, indicating dependence on God's provision through Boaz. This echoes biblical theology of God working through means (cf. Genesis 50:20; Romans 8:28; Psalm 23:1-3; Philippians 4:19). Ruth's humility and trust exemplify the believer's posture toward God's sovereign care.

questions.question: What does Boaz’s greeting to the reapers, 'The LORD be with you' and their response, 'The LORD bless thee' (Ruth 2:4), teach about the role of God's blessing in everyday work?
options: It shows that God's blessing is invoked in ordinary labor, affirming its sacredness
It indicates that only priests can bless others
It suggests that Boaz was testing the loyalty of his workers
It reveals a magical incantation to increase the harvest
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that God's blessing is invoked in ordinary labor, affirming its sacredness
questions.explanation: The exchange in Ruth 2:4 highlights that God's blessing is integral in daily work and community life, reflecting the biblical view that all labor is under God's sovereign care (cf. Genesis 2:15; Ecclesiastes 3:13; Colossians 3:23; Psalm 128:2). This affirms the sacredness of work and the community’s dependence on God.

questions.question: Why does Boaz instruct Ruth not to glean in any other field but to 'abide here fast by my maidens' (Ruth 2:8)?
options: To ensure her protection and to provide her with abundant provision
Because Boaz wanted to keep her isolated from others
Because Ruth was not allowed to work in other fields by law
Because there was no other field nearby
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure her protection and to provide her with abundant provision
questions.explanation: Boaz's instruction in Ruth 2:8 is an act of kindness and protection, ensuring Ruth's safety and access to resources. This reflects God's care for the vulnerable (cf. Deuteronomy 24:19-21; Psalm 68:5; James 1:27; Isaiah 1:17). Boaz acts as a guardian figure, foreshadowing Christ as protector of the vulnerable.

questions.question: What theological truth is reflected in Boaz’s declaration, 'The LORD recompense thy work, and a full reward be given thee of the LORD God of Israel' (Ruth 2:12)?
options: God is righteous and rewards faithfulness and kindness
Boaz claims divine authority to give blessings
Rewards are guaranteed only for Israelites
God rewards only those who marry Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: God is righteous and rewards faithfulness and kindness
questions.explanation: Boaz's blessing in Ruth 2:12 acknowledges God's justice and grace in rewarding loyal and selfless acts. This echoes biblical principles that God honors faithfulness regardless of nationality (cf. Proverbs 11:18; Matthew 5:7; Hebrews 6:10; Galatians 6:9). It highlights God's impartiality and covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Ruth’s humility in bowing to the ground and saying, 'Why have I found grace in thine eyes, seeing I am a stranger?' (Ruth 2:10) illustrate a key aspect of salvation theology?
options: It reflects recognition of unworthiness and God’s sovereign grace to the outsider
It shows that only strangers receive grace
It implies Ruth doubted Boaz’s intentions
It suggests self-righteousness in seeking favor
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects recognition of unworthiness and God’s sovereign grace to the outsider
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:10 reveals her humble awareness of being an outsider and unworthy, yet finding favor—mirroring salvation theology where grace is unmerited favor extended to the undeserving (cf. Ephesians 2:8-9; Luke 15:20-24; Isaiah 53:6; Romans 5:8). This highlights God’s mercy to Gentiles and sinners.

questions.question: What does Boaz’s knowledge of Ruth’s loyalty to Naomi, 'all that thou hast done unto thy mother in law' (Ruth 2:11), indicate about God’s providential oversight?
options: God sees and rewards faithfulness and covenant loyalty even in difficult circumstances
Boaz was spying on Ruth
Naomi informed Boaz of Ruth’s actions
Boaz was suspicious of Ruth’s motives
questions.correctAnswer: God sees and rewards faithfulness and covenant loyalty even in difficult circumstances
questions.explanation: Boaz’s awareness (Ruth 2:11) exemplifies God's providence, seeing human faithfulness and rewarding it (cf. Psalm 34:15; Hebrews 6:10; Genesis 39:2-3; Matthew 25:21). Ruth’s loyalty echoes covenant faithfulness, foreshadowing Christ’s redeeming loyalty to His bride.

questions.question: How does Boaz’s invitation to Ruth to 'come hither, and eat of the bread, and dip thy morsel in the vinegar' (Ruth 2:14) symbolize Christological themes of provision and fellowship?
options: It prefigures Christ’s invitation to partake in His sustaining grace and fellowship
It was a common hospitality custom with no deeper meaning
It symbolizes a covenant of marriage
It represents a ritual cleansing
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures Christ’s invitation to partake in His sustaining grace and fellowship
questions.explanation: Boaz’s meal invitation in Ruth 2:14 points to God’s provision and acceptance, prefiguring Christ’s call to partake in spiritual nourishment and fellowship (cf. John 6:35; Revelation 3:20; Matthew 26:26-28; Isaiah 55:1). It highlights God’s grace inviting the outsider into community.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is demonstrated by Boaz commanding his young men to 'let her glean even among the sheaves' and to 'leave them, that she may glean them' (Ruth 2:15-16)?
options: God’s grace provides generously and beyond mere obligation to the needy
It shows Boaz’s reluctance to share his harvest
It implies that Ruth was a servant with limited rights
It reveals a legalistic approach to charity
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace provides generously and beyond mere obligation to the needy
questions.explanation: Boaz’s generosity (Ruth 2:15-16) reflects God’s abundant grace which goes beyond legal requirements (cf. Deuteronomy 24:19-22; 2 Corinthians 9:6-8; Luke 6:38; James 2:15-16). This grace is a hallmark of God’s kingdom, where the vulnerable are cared for abundantly.

questions.question: Why is it significant that Ruth gleaned about an ephah of barley by evening (Ruth 2:17)?
options: It demonstrates God’s blessing on faithful labor and foreshadows spiritual harvest
It was an insignificant amount of grain
It shows Ruth’s lack of skill
It implies that the harvest was poor that year
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God’s blessing on faithful labor and foreshadows spiritual harvest
questions.explanation: The large quantity Ruth gleaned (Ruth 2:17) reflects God’s blessing on diligence and faithfulness (cf. Proverbs 10:4; Matthew 9:37-38; Galatians 6:9; John 4:35). The harvest imagery also points forward to eschatological themes of fruitfulness and reward.

questions.question: How does Naomi’s blessing for Boaz, 'Blessed be he of the LORD, who hath not left off his kindness to the living and to the dead' (Ruth 2:20), reflect God’s covenant faithfulness?
options: It affirms God’s enduring mercy and kindness across generations
It means Boaz was a priest
It suggests Boaz was only kind to the living
It implies that kindness is irrelevant to God’s covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God’s enduring mercy and kindness across generations
questions.explanation: Naomi’s blessing (Ruth 2:20) highlights God’s covenantal kindness that transcends life and death, consistent with biblical promises (cf. Exodus 34:6; Psalm 103:17; Lamentations 3:22-23; Romans 11:29). This underscores God’s faithfulness to His people and their descendants.

questions.question: What theological implication arises from Ruth’s statement that Boaz told her to 'keep fast by my young men until they have ended all my harvest' (Ruth 2:21)?
options: It signifies God’s provision and protection will continue until the work is complete
It means Ruth was bound as a servant until harvest’s end
It indicates that Ruth was forbidden to leave Boaz’s fields
It suggests that Boaz was controlling Ruth’s movements
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies God’s provision and protection will continue until the work is complete
questions.explanation: Ruth 2:21 symbolizes continuous divine care and protection throughout the season, illustrating God’s faithfulness until His purposes are fulfilled (cf. Philippians 1:6; Psalm 121:3; 2 Timothy 4:7; Hebrews 13:5). The harvest metaphor implies spiritual perseverance and reward.

questions.question: How does Naomi’s advice to Ruth, 'It is good, my daughter, that thou go out with his maidens, that they meet thee not in any other field' (Ruth 2:22), demonstrate wisdom rooted in God’s providence?
options: It shows the importance of wise counsel and trusting God’s protective provision
It was a legal requirement for widows
It implies Naomi distrusted Ruth’s judgment
It suggests Ruth was not allowed to work elsewhere
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the importance of wise counsel and trusting God’s protective provision
questions.explanation: Naomi’s counsel (Ruth 2:22) reflects practical wisdom aligning with trust in God’s providence (cf. Proverbs 11:14; James 1:5; Psalm 32:8; Ecclesiastes 7:12). This demonstrates how God’s care operates through godly advice and community.

questions.question: What does Ruth’s continued gleaning 'unto the end of barley harvest and of wheat harvest' (Ruth 2:23) teach about perseverance in faith and obedience?
options: Faithful perseverance leads to God’s sustained blessing and provision
Ruth was forced to work without rest
It indicates that Ruth was a hired laborer
It shows that harvest seasons were short
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful perseverance leads to God’s sustained blessing and provision
questions.explanation: Ruth’s persistence (Ruth 2:23) exemplifies steadfast faith and obedience, which Scripture commends (cf. Hebrews 12:1-2; James 1:12; Galatians 6:9; Romans 5:3-5). Her endurance results in God’s ongoing blessing and protection.

questions.question: How does the interaction between Boaz and Ruth in Ruth 2 reveal the doctrine of God’s inclusive grace?
options: It shows God’s grace extends to Gentiles and outsiders who trust Him
It restricts God’s grace only to Israelites
It teaches that only married women can receive God’s grace
It suggests grace is earned by good works
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God’s grace extends to Gentiles and outsiders who trust Him
questions.explanation: Ruth, a Moabitess (Ruth 2:6), receives favor and protection, demonstrating God’s grace transcending ethnic boundaries (cf. Jonah 4:11; Acts 10:34-35; Galatians 3:28; Ephesians 2:11-22). This foreshadows the gospel’s universal offer to all nations.

questions.question: What messianic foreshadowing is found in Boaz’s role as a kinsman redeemer providing for Ruth and Naomi?
options: Boaz prefigures Christ as the ultimate Redeemer who restores and provides for His people
Boaz is a type of the high priest offering sacrifices
Boaz represents an angelic figure
Boaz symbolizes the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz prefigures Christ as the ultimate Redeemer who restores and provides for His people
questions.explanation: Boaz’s role (Ruth 2:1, 20) as a near kinsman who redeems and protects illustrates Christ’s redemptive work (cf. Isaiah 59:20; Galatians 4:4-5; Hebrews 9:12; Romans 8:34). This typology reveals God’s plan of salvation through Jesus.

questions.question: How does Ruth 2 emphasize the attribute of God’s faithfulness in the context of human vulnerability and need?
options: God’s faithfulness is shown through provision and protection for the marginalized
God is indifferent to human suffering
God’s faithfulness depends on human merit
God’s faithfulness is only for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness is shown through provision and protection for the marginalized
questions.explanation: Throughout Ruth 2, God’s faithfulness is evident as He provides for Ruth and Naomi (Ruth 2:12, 16, 20). This aligns with biblical teaching that God cares for widows, orphans, and foreigners (cf. Deuteronomy 10:18; Psalm 146:9; James 1:27; Lamentations 3:22-23). It highlights God’s covenant loyalty to vulnerable people.
